name: heavy mineral sand quarry operation and titania slag production | titania slag, 85% titanium dioxide | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/19721/documentation

Heavy mineral sands are a class of ore deposit which is an important source heavy minerals - hence the name. The density of these mineral is generally above 2.9 gr/cm3. Important heavy mineral are: zirconium, titanium, thorium, tungsten, rare-earth elements, the industrial minerals diamond, sapphire, garnet, and occasionally precious metals or gemstones (kyanite, tourmaline, titanite, apatite). ;;The source materials of heavy mineral sand are metamorphic and igneous rocks. Metamorphic rocks give rise to sand containing kyanite and garnet, for example, although the latter may crystallise from magma as well. Magnetite is mostly of igneous origin. ;;Heavy mineral sands are placer deposits formed most usually in beach environments by concentration due to the specific gravity of the mineral grains. It is equally likely that some concentrations of heavy minerals (aside from the usual gold placers) exist within streambeds, but most are of a low grade and are relatively small.; ;Heavy mineral sand is a natural mineral concentrate which is often mined commercially. Zircon, gold, ilmenite, rutile, monazite, and cassiterite are some noteworthy heavy minerals that are often extracted from sand. Heavy mineral sand is not rare, but its area of occurrence is usually limited.

Activities include the harvesting of the sands via a system of ponds and floating dredges and the concentration, done on a floating gravity separation plant. The concentrator produces two streams, which are transported to the second location where the Mineral Separation Plant (MSP) and the smelter are situated. 

At the MSP the various minerals are separated to produce zircon, rutile and ilmenite. 
The ilmenite is smelted to produce titania slag (85% TiO2) as Reference product: more high quality (low manganese content) pig iron is produced as a by-product in this stage.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data spans over a period of 4 years (2012-2015), although the most recent and complete year (2015) was used ad year of reference.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Heavy mineral sands in South Africa: Two major heavy mineral sands companies were identified. The first is Richards Bay Minerals (RBM) which is the biggest producer of titania slag in South Africa. The second company is Tronox which has an operation in the Western Cape named Namakwa Sands and an operation in KwaZulu Natal named KZN Sands. A third minor heavy mineral sands company called Tormin was identified. This company is located in the Western Cape, it does not however produce titania slag.;;Tronox are a vertically integrated company. They produce titania slag in their South African operations and ship the slag to their titanium dioxide and pigment plants overseas. Thus the titania slag produced by Tronox never enters the local or global market. For this reason the Tronox operations are not being accounted for in this LCI for HMS with titania slag (85% TiO¬2) as the reference product.  ;;Richards Bay Minerals are the largest heavy mineral sands operation in South Africa and are not a vertically integrated company, thus their titania slag enters the local global market. Table 1 below shows the size of the Rio Tintos RBM operation in relation to the two other companies operations for the year 2015. From these results we are confident that modelling the LCI on HMS for South Africa on the RBM operations is accurate.;;It is worth noting that there are two distinct methods of mining heavy mineral sands in South Africa: dredge mining and truck and shovel mining. RBM and KZN sands utilises the first, while Namakwa Sands utilises the latter. ;;South Africa contributes to world market share of about 25 per cent of titanium dioxide feedstock (titania slag and rutile), 33 per cent of the world’s zircon output and 25 per cent of the world’s high purity pig iron.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Richards Bay Minerals is situated north of Richards Bay in Zululand, within the uThungulu District Municipality. This is in the North-Eastern region of the province KwaZulu-Natal.;The mineral sands are harvested via a system of ponds and floating dredges and the concentration is done on a floating gravity separation plant. These two stages of the process take place in the same location. The concentrator produces two streams: a magnetic and non-magnetic stream. The magnetic stream consists of ilmenite while the non-magnetic stream consists of zircon and rutile. ;This concentrate is transported to the second location where the Mineral Separation Plant (MSP) and the smelter are situated. At the MSP the various minerals are separated to produce zircon, rutile and ilmenite.;The ilmenite is smelted to produce titania slag (85% TiO2). High quality (low manganese content) pig iron is produced as a by-product in this stage. The ilmenite first undergoes an oxidizing roast followed by magnetic separation where the Cr2O3 fraction of the ilmenite is removed. The ilmenite is then partially reduced to 85% TiO2 slag in a six-in-line A.C. electric arc furnace
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: From 2012 onwards, the reports no longer reported the data numerically and changed to reporting it graphically. Because of this, in order to get numerical values, a programme called Inkscape was used to extract numerical values from the graphs in the SDRs.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
The data was collected from the published 2012 and 2015 Sustainable Development Reports.  Additional information was found in academic reports and journals;                                                                            Richards Bay Minerals, 2015 Sustainable Development Report (RBM, 2015)
Richards Bay Minerals, 2012 Sustainable Development Repor t(RBM, 2012)
Philander, C. and Rozendaal, A., 2013. The application of a novel geometallurgical template model to characterise the Namakwa Sands heavy mineral deposit, West Coast of South Africa. Minerals Engineering, 52, pp.82-94.

exchanges.description:
For the year 2015 the SDR’s did not report this value as a numerical value, but rather graphically. Thus the programme Inkscape was used to determine the value.
The total concentrate produced by RBM was given in a diagram. This was multiplied by the percentage of the concentrate that was titania slag in order to give the value for Titania Slag (85% TiO2)
The percentage was: 53,41%

The percentage was calculated by finding the average ratio of the products produced by RBM from 2010 to 2012. 
% Titania slag =  (Sum of Titania slag produced from 2010 to 2012)/(Sum of all products produced from 2010 to 2012).                                         The largest application of titania slag is as a white pigment representing between the 95 and 98 % of worldwide TiO2 consumption. The remaining uses are as a flux for electric welding rods and in certain metallurgical and electronic applications. Being non toxic and biologically passive, it is even used in sweets, cosmetics, toothpaste and in sunscreens to absorb ultraviolet rays.

exchanges.description: This represent the fuel used to produce the heat for the smelter. This has been obtained by multiplying the anthracite (coal) calorifc value by the enegry consumption (redported in the SD report, see below) due to the burning of the anthracite. The reported value for the total energy consumption it was assumed to be for heating: sources are anthracite (mainly), electrodes, diesel, pertrol, paraffing and carbide. For the year 2015 the SDR’s did not report this value as a numerical value, but rather graphically. Thus the programme Inkscape was used to determine the value. Annual consumption of MJ 7340183,282, corresponding anthracite value of 199 493 457 kg.

flow.name: Zirconium
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in ground

exchanges.description:
For the year 2015 the SDR’s did not report this value as a numerical value, but rather graphically. Thus the programme Inkscape was used to determine the value. Annual consuption of kWh 2138142350 was determined from the RBM, 2015 SD report using the following procedure:                                                      from the given picture in the SDR and there are no calibrations to accurately determine the value of electricity (GJ) for 2015. There Inkscape was used as it has a built in ruler. The following steps were taken:
 1-A ratio was determined by using the point circled in red. One knows can determine, using the built in ruler, that 2 000 000 GJ corresponds to 36.01 units on inkscape. Therefore the ratio is 2000000/36.01.
2-Thus for 2015 the built in ruler was used to determine the length from the Y-axis to the point circle in blue: 138,59 units. 
3-The electricity usage for 2015 was thus 138,59 * (2000000/36.01).
4-This value was then converted from GJ to kWh and then rescaled to 1 kg of titania slag produce.

exchanges.description:
This value was calculated from subtracting the surface water (‘total water withdrawn from source’) from ‘total water consumed per operation’.   Annual consumption of m3 18685675,39
. 


The values of total water consumed per operation is only reported until 2012.  The 2015 SDR only gives “Total water withdrawal by source”.
A graph was plotted for total water consumed per operation vs titania slag production. A trendline was used from Microsoft Excel with the equation
y = 22 993 885,20ln(x) - 445 537 813,22.
The y-value is the total water consumed per operation (m3). The 2015 value for Titania Slag produced (x-value) was used to calculate the 2015 total water consumed per operation value.
